Within the area, loose and unattended objects that weigh up to 25 pounds are flung around you in a lethal orbit. The area within the storm counts as magical difficult terrain. Projectiles and other ranged weapon attacks that enter the area are immediately picked up by the storm, so these attacks automatically miss. Any creature who enters the area or starts their turn in the area is buffeted and battered by the swirling debris and must make a Dexterity saving throw. They take {@dice 5d8|5d8 force|Force Damage} damage on a failure or half of that on a success. This feature requires {@condition concentration|PHB} to maintain, and you can maintain it for up to 1 Minute. While you maintain {@condition concentration|PHB} on this feature, you are immune to its effects, and every round that you maintain {@condition concentration|PHB}, you can use a bonus action to grow the sphere by a 10-foot radius increment.

subclassFeature.name: Greater Telekinesis
entries: Your telekinetic abilities have grown to incredible levels. At 15th level, when you use {@subclassFeature Basic Telekinesis|Armiger|TheArmigerClass|Scarred|TheArmigerClass|3|TheArmigerClass}, you can pick up objects that weigh up to 25 pounds instead of 10 pounds.

Additionally, when you use {@subclassFeature Telekinetic Projectile|Armiger|TheArmigerClass|Scarred|TheArmigerClass|3|TheArmigerClass}, you can expend any number of available links to increase its potency. For every link spent, you increase the damage by {@dice 1d6} and the range is increased by 5 feet.
Finally, you learn the following link features:

subclassFeature.name: Mass Telekinetic Hold
entries: As an action, you can expend 6 links to telekinetically pin all targeted creatures within 30 feet of you. Any creatures you designate within 30 feet of you must make a Constitution saving throw or be {@condition incapacitated|PHB} and {@condition restrained|PHB}. At the start of each of a creature's turns, it can reattempt the saving throw to end the effect. You may only use this feature once per short rest.

subclassFeature.name: Unstoppable Resilience
entries: You won't let anything stop you. Not anymore. At 18th level, you gain resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from nonmagical attacks, and you can add your Charisma modifier to any Constitution ability checks or saving throws.
Finally, you learn the Mass Telekinetic Hold link feature:

subclassFeature.name: Balance the Scales
entries: As an action, you can expend 1 link to create a balancing effect on two creatures within 30 feet of you. Choose one of the balancing effects listed below. All targets receive a Wisdom saving throw to resist the effect, though a target can choose to fail the save. If either one of the targets saves against the effect, the entire feature ends. Maintaining this feature requires {@condition concentration|PHB}, and it can only last up to 1 Minute.

items: {@b Balance Aptitude.} One creature you choose gains advantage to a skill, and the other receives disadvantage to the same skill.
{@b Balance Defenses.} One creature you choose gains a +1 bonus to their AC, and the other receives a -1 penalty to their AC.
{@b Balance Prowess.} One creature you choose gains a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls, and the other receives a -1 penalty to attack and damage rolls.
{@b Balance Resistance.} One creature you choose gains a +1 bonus to a saving throw of your choice, and the other receives a -1 penalty to the same saving throw.
{@b Balance Speed.} One creature you choose gains a +10 foot bonus to their speed, and the other receives a -10 foot penalty to their speed. This cannot reduce a creature's speed below 5.

subclassFeature.name: Even the Odds
entries: You can use your connection to harmony to stabilize odds. Once per short rest, whenever a creature you see makes an ability check (including yourself), you can use your reaction to force the roll result to be 10, as if a 10 was rolled instead of whatever was actually rolled. You must declare you are using this feature before the check is resolved.
Also at 3rd level, you learn the Balance the Scales link feature:

subclassFeature.name: Symmetry Inheritance
entries: {@i Push. Pull. In. Out. Give. Take. Good. Evil. Life. Death. Armigers of the Symmetry inheritance are especially attuned to the ways all things are interconnected with one another, and can take advantage of these connections to both devastate their enemies and benefit their allies. Symmetry armigers are often the most sage of the armigers, as their keen awareness of how one thing can affect another encourages them to be mindful of their own actions and how they might affect those around them. They know that every action has an equal and opposite reaction, and it's this basic principle that inspires them to seek out ways they can utilize the harmonious cycles found in all things for their own purposes.}

{@i Symmetry armigers' arsenals often reflect the cycles or dualities that the armiger is especially interested in. For example, an armiger focused on the metaphysical war between good and evil, may have an armory that mixes both abyssal and celestial aesthetics, their bonded weaponry may have black-and-white coloring, and their links may appear as transparent wings around their head that fluctuate between feathered and leather wings. A more alchemical or commerce-minded symmetry armiger may connect with the idea of equivalent exchanges, and their armory may appear as a trading post or other place of transaction. Their bonded weaponry may flip themselves over when not in use, and their links may appear as a collection of 2-sided coins.}

subclassFeature.name: Life Transfer
entries: As an action, you can expend 3 links to unleash a 15-foot radius burst around yourself that transfers the lifeforce of enemies to allies. Enemies in the burst must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failure, they take {@dice 2d8} of the damage type that you chose for the Balance the Four Humors feature. Enemies that successfully save suffer no damage. Thereafter, you can heal allies in the burst (including yourself) with an amount of health equal to half the damage inflicted. You can portion out the hit points as you please, but the cumulative amount of health healed cannot exceed half of the damage inflicted by this ability.

subclassFeature.name: Balance the Four Humors
entries: You are especially attuned to physical imbalances and can take advantage of them to both harm enemies and heal allies. At 7th level, {@b choose acid, necrotic, radiant, or force}. You can change this decision whenever you take a long rest. You gain resistance to the damage type chosen.

Also at 7th level, you gain proficiency in the {@skill Medicine} skill and can use Charisma instead of Wisdom for all Medicine skill checks. You do not need to physically touch a creature you are making Medicine checks on. Instead, you can make Medicine checks up to a range of 30 feet away by manipulating the humors of the creature. Additionally, you learn the {@spell Spare the Dying} cantrip. You can cast this cantrip as a bonus action instead of an action and from a range of 30 feet instead of touch.
Finally, you learn the Life Transfer link feature:

subclassFeature.name: Empowered Balance the Scales
entries: As {@subclassFeature Balance the Scales|Armiger|TheArmigerClass|Symmetry|TheArmigerClass|3|TheArmigerClass}, except you can expend 4 links to have the balancing effects improved as follows:

items: {@b Empowered Balance Aptitude.} One creature you choose gains advantage to a skill, and the other receives disadvantage to the same skill.
{@b Empowered Balance Defenses.} One creature you choose gains a +1 bonus to their AC, and the other receives a -1 penalty to their AC.
{@b Empowered Balance Prowess.} One creature you choose gains a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls, and the other receives a -1 penalty to attack and damage rolls.
{@b Empowered Balance Resistance.} One creature you choose gains a +1 bonus to a saving throw of your choice, and the other receives a -1 penalty to the same saving throw.
{@b Empowered Balance Speed.} One creature you choose gains a +10 foot bonus to their speed, and the other receives a -10 foot penalty to their speed. This cannot reduce a creature's speed below 5.

subclassFeature.name: Level the Field
entries: Your connection to balance keeps growing and your power along with it. At 11th level, your {@subclassFeature Balance the Scales|Armiger|TheArmigerClass|Symmetry|TheArmigerClass|3|TheArmigerClass} link feature can now affect all creatures in a 30-foot radius of you, though each individual creature can still make a Wisdom saving throw to resist the effect as normal. You may designate which creatures benefit from the bonus and which creatures receive the penalty of your balancing effect.

Additionally, when a creature saves against the effect, it no longer ends the entire feature for everyone else. You still need at least 1 creature on either side of the balancing effect. Should 0 creatures be receiving the bonus or the penalty of a balancing effect, it ends for everyone.
Finally, you can amplify your balancing effects by expending 3 additional links (4 links total) when using the feature, as described below:

subclassFeature.name: Absolute Symmetry
entries: Your connection to harmonious cycles has almost reached the point of perfection. At 15th level, your {@subclassFeature Life Transfer|Armiger|TheArmigerClass|Symmetry|TheArmigerClass|7|TheArmigerClass} link feature improves as follows:

items: Your {@subclassFeature Life Transfer|Armiger|TheArmigerClass|Symmetry|TheArmigerClass|7|TheArmigerClass} grows to a 30-foot radius burst, and its damage increases to 4d8 of the relevant damage type instead of 2d8.

When a creature saves against the {@subclassFeature Life Transfer|Armiger|TheArmigerClass|Symmetry|TheArmigerClass|7|TheArmigerClass}, they still suffer half damage, and the damage inflicted gets added to the healing pool of hit points.

You can now heal an amount of health equal to the damage inflicted by the {@subclassFeature Life Transfer|Armiger|TheArmigerClass|Symmetry|TheArmigerClass|7|TheArmigerClass}, instead of half of the damage inflicted.

entries: Finally, you are a master at harmonizing imbalances. You now make all Medicine checks with advantage.

subclassFeature.name: Perfectly Balanced as All Things Should Be
entries: You have reached the point of ultimate harmony, balance, and symmetry, and you are perfected. At 18th level, you gain the Monk's {@classFeature Purity of Body|Monk|PHB|10} and {@classFeature Timeless Body|Monk|PHB|15} features.

Also, when you use your {@subclassFeature Life Transfer|Armiger|TheArmigerClass|Symmetry|TheArmigerClass|7|TheArmigerClass} link feature, as a bonus action you can expend 5 links to impose one of your improved balancing effects from {@subclassFeature Empowered Balance the Scales|Armiger|TheArmigerClass|Symmetry|TheArmigerClass|11|TheArmigerClass}. When you do this, any creatures who fail their Constitution saving throw against the {@subclassFeature Life Transfer|Armiger|TheArmigerClass|Symmetry|TheArmigerClass|7|TheArmigerClass} also automatically fail their Wisdom saving throw against the balancing effect.

subclassFeature.name: Armored Guard
entries: At 3rd level, your ability to use armor is extraordinary. You gain proficiency in heavy armor. You also ignore strength requirements for wearing armor, so you do not have your speed reduced when you do not meet the requirements.
While wearing medium or heavy armor, you can use the {@spell Blade Ward} cantrip at will using Charisma as your spellcasting ability, and you can choose to cast the spell as a bonus action.

subclassFeature.name: Ward Ally
entries: As a reaction when an ally you see within 30 feet of you has an attack roll made against them, you can expend 1 link to send a bonded shield to defend them. The ally gains a +2 AC bonus against the triggering attack and all attacks made against them until the start of your next turn, which is when the bonded shield returns to you.

subclassFeature.name: Bonded Shields
entries: Also at 3rd level, you can bond to shields with the {@classFeature Bonded Weaponry|Armiger|TheArmigerClass|1|TheArmigerClass} feature. When you bond to a shield, the bonded shield functions as a {@item club|PHB} ({@dice 1d4|1d4 bludgeoning|Bludgeoning Damage}) for attack and damage calculations, and you can use bonded shields as a bonded weapon for other armiger features - such as {@classFeature Armiger's Armory|Armiger|TheArmigerClass|1|TheArmigerClass} and {@classFeature Telumkinesis|Armiger|TheArmigerClass|1|TheArmigerClass}. A bonded shield counts as worn and confers its bonus to AC when in a hovering position around you, but not when it is no longer in your possession, such as after having been launched in a {@classFeature Grand Strike|Armiger|TheArmigerClass|2|TheArmigerClass}.
Having multiple bonded shields does not confer an additional bonus to AC.
Additionally, the additional attunement slots you get at 13th and 20th level can also be used to attune to shields or armor, instead of just weapons.
Finally, you learn the Ward Ally link feature that only works when you have a bonded shield available:

subclassFeature.name: Vanguard Inheritance
entries: {@i Vanguard armigers are battlefield commanders. Often stalwart and taking up arms at the head of armies, vanguard armigers tend to be strategic fighters that lead their allies in glorious combat. They connect to such things as warfare, fervor, strength, or tactics, and feel at home amongst the clash of steel. Vanguard armigers are often more cerebral and calculating than their peers, and they especially excel in matters concerning teamwork, battle strategies, and combat techniques. Vanguard armigers are called to fight in a way no other armiger is, and this often makes them keen to tackle challenges head on. Still, what perhaps makes vanguard armigers such impressive figures is their ability to empower their allies to higher performance. Even a volunteer militia becomes a well-oiled force when a vanguard armiger takes charge.}

{@i The bonded weaponry of vanguard armigers take on many forms, but they almost always look like masterwork equipment shining as if freshly polished. They reflect light with such clarity that they can often be seen at incredible distances. Meanwhile, their armories reflect places of combat or training, such as gladiatorial arenas, sparring grounds, or military barracks. The links of vanguard armigers take inspiration from battle and war. A sadistic vanguard armiger might have streaks of blood circling their armor, while a vanguard armiger devoted to defending their allies might have links that appear as ornamental rondels running up their arms. Meanwhile, a vanguard armiger from a war tribe might use their links as magically shifting warpaint markings on their face.}

subclassFeature.name: Brace Yourselves!
entries: As an action, you can expend 3 links to give all allies who can see you a bonus to their AC equal to your Charisma modifier on the next attack made against them. This bonus disappears after one attack, but otherwise, it lasts until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Follow Up the Attack!
entries: As a reaction when you damage a creature with a successful {@action Attack} action, you can expend 3 links to have one other ally you can see take the {@action Attack} action against the same creature you just damaged. (If you damage multiple creatures at once, you may target one of them.) If the chosen ally is unable to make an attack against the creature for any reason, this feature immediately fails. The ally cannot use this action to do anything other than {@action Attack} (e.g. they cannot {@action Cast a Spell} with this action).

subclassFeature.name: Move It!
entries: As a bonus action, you can expend 3 links to have one other creature you can see immediately move up to their speed. This movement does not provoke opportunity attacks.

subclassFeature.name: Strategic Command
entries: Your connection to your allies and to the battlefield allows you to take control in an extraordinary way. At 7th level, immediately after initiative is rolled but before a turn has begun, you may declare that you are taking strategic command. When you do, you may swap the initiatives of one willing ally with one other willing ally (including yourself). You can only use this feature once per long rest.
Additionally, you learn the following link features:

subclassFeature.name: Combat Inspiration
entries: As a reaction when you damage a creature, you can expend 3 links to give one other ally who can see you a die of Combat Inspiration. This die is a d4. Once within the next 1 Minute, the ally can roll the Combat Inspiration die and add the number rolled to one attack roll or to their AC against one attack roll made against them. An ally can wait until after the appropriate roll is made before deciding to use the Combat Inspiration die, but they must decide before the DM says whether the roll succeeds or fails. Once the Combat Inspiration die is rolled, it is lost. A creature can only ever have one die of Combat Inspiration at one time, and Combat Inspiration dice do not stack.

subclassFeature.name: Link Feature: Combat Inspiration
entries: You motivate your allies from the middle of the fray; your success becomes their success. At 11th level, you learn the Combat Inspiration link feature:

subclassFeature.name: Living Banner
entries: You are more than just a standard bearer; you are the banner itself. At 15th level, as long as you are not unconscious, all other allies who can see you have a bonus to saves against {@condition charmed} and {@condition frightened} equal to your Charisma modifier. Also, your {@subclassFeature Combat Inspiration|Armiger|TheArmigerClass|Vanguard|TheArmigerClass|11|TheArmigerClass} die is now d6 instead of d4.

Additionally, when you use {@subclassFeature Strategic Command|Armiger|TheArmigerClass|Vanguard|TheArmigerClass|7|TheArmigerClass} to swap initiative, you can choose to roll 1d4-1 and make a number of willing ally initiative swap pairs equal to the result of your roll (e.g. a result of 3 means you make 3 pairs of initiative swaps). Your final result can be 0, and in that case, you are unable to make any initiative swaps. Rolling a 0 still counts as using the feature, meaning you need to take a long rest before you can use this feature again.

subclassFeature.name: Victory!
entries: As an action, you can expend 6 links to impart extraordinary power in your allies. All other allies who can see you when you use this action gain one of your {@subclassFeature Combat Inspiration|Armiger|TheArmigerClass|Vanguard|TheArmigerClass|11|TheArmigerClass} dice. Additionally, they gain a number of temporary hit points equal to your armiger level that last until they take a short or long rest. You can only use this feature once per short rest.

Your {@subclassFeature Combat Inspiration|Armiger|TheArmigerClass|Vanguard|TheArmigerClass|11|TheArmigerClass} is now d8 instead of d6, and the {@subclassFeature Ward Ally|Armiger|TheArmigerClass|Vanguard|TheArmigerClass|3|TheArmigerClass} link feature no longer costs any links.

item.name: Armiger's Bonded Weapon
entries: A weapon bonded to an {@class armiger|TheArmigerClass}. Such a weapon has undergone {@classFeature Bonded Weaponry|Armiger|TheArmigerClass|1|TheArmigerClass|a bonding ritual} to an {@class armiger|TheArmigerClass} and has the following additional properties when used by the {@class armiger|TheArmigerClass} it is bonded to:

items: {@b Arsenal.} The bonded weapon can be used for its bonded armiger's other {@class armiger|TheArmigerClass} features.
{@b Glamoured.} The bonded weapon takes on any superficial changes that its bonded armiger likes. These changes are purely aesthetic and do not affect the weapon's functionality.

{@b Hover.} The bonded weapon can hover harmlessly around its bonded armiger. While hovering, the weapon stays within 5 feet of its bonded armiger (remaining in their space) and counts as being in its bonded armiger's possession. The bonded weapon's bonded armiger may add their Charisma modifier on any saves or ability checks to resist having a hovering bonded weapon disarmed, stolen, or otherwise taken from them.

{@b Summon.} The bonded weapon can be summoned into its bonded armiger's hand as a bonus action, as long as it is within 1 Mile of its bonded armiger or in their armory. If a bonded weapon is in the possession of another creature when its bonded armiger tries to summon it, the creature may make a contested Charisma check to resist the weapon being summoned. If the creature succeeds, the weapon does not return to the armiger.

entries: A bonded weapon loses its bond (and relevant properties) if it is separated from its bonded armiger's possession for 1 hour.

entries.name: The Armiger
entries: The wealthy weapon collector raises his eyebrow at the oncoming highwaymen. They assumed he was unarmed, and while the collector had no weapon physically on him, the highwaymen were mistaken in thinking he was without them. As golden weapons begin to shoot out from golden portals, the collector relaxes into the seat of his carriage, comfortable knowing that the bandits would soon be dealt with.

The charming dancer pleases the audience with her impressive ax juggling, but the audience is completely beguiled when the glowing axes suddenly disappear into thin air. That is, except for the dancer's quarry in the front row, who suddenly feels a blade in his torso. Bounties paid more than show business anyways.

The elven commander was a legend among their troops. They were known for having lost both hands in battle, yes, but they were even more well-known for being able to control their vast collection of weapons with subtle movements of their body. The saying went that so long as their commander could move their eyes, the army would remain undefeated.

Armigers are manipulators of weapons in a way that no one else is. Able to control weapons via the connections they create with their arsenals, Armigers aren't just defined by their unique power or by their incredible presence, but by their bonds.

entries.name: Bonded and Connected
entries: All armigers share a distinct ability to bond with their weapons, connecting to weapons in an extraordinary way that allows them to manipulate them in a variety of manners. Unlike mage hand users or simple telekinetics, armigers can deftly control many weapons and utilize them in ways that exceed simple strikes. In addition to their bonded weaponry, all armigers can access an extra dimensional storage space called the armiger's armory. Herein, armigers can store their weapon collections. These armories often evolve in size and appearance, growing with their armiger. At the highest level, some armigers can even manifest their armory like a demiplane. Because of how much an armiger relies on their arsenal, many armigers tend to be weapon collectors, blacksmiths, or otherwise interested in weapons beyond the norm; for each new weapon is a new part of the armiger.

An armiger's power is more than just their combat prowess. Armigers are memorable figures whose personalities are as strong as their arsenals. The armiger's charisma comes from the fact that their powers are based on their ability to connect. Whether with weapons or with people, armigers are people who are especially apt at bonding with things outside of themselves - for better and for worse. This doesn't mean that all armigers are automatically likable. Many nefarious armigers exist who use their natural presence to manipulate and control those around them. Still, more benevolent armigers also exist, who wield their influence to empower people and lead them to great acts. Regardless, all armigers are a force to be reckoned with, whether due to their force of personality or the force of their arsenals.

entries.name: To Grow Their Bonds
entries: To an armiger, bonds are everything. Their bonded weaponry, for example, aren't just tools but extensions of themselves. In fact, an armiger's arsenal often reflects the personality of the armiger, evolving new features that reflect who the armiger is. And, the bonds that armigers make with people, creatures, places, ideas, and experiences are just as important to them. In the same way a {@item Armiger's Bonded Weapon|TheArmigerClass|bonded weapon} is influenced by the armiger bonded with them, the connections that armigers make can influence armigers in powerful ways. Without their bonds, not only do the armiger's abilities suffer, but perhaps most pitiful of all, so does the armiger's sense of self suffer, too.

As such, armigers - though rare overall - are almost always adventurers. Whether for king and country or home and hearth, armigers undertake all manner of quests and do all manner of deeds in an effort to strengthen the connections they have and to grow new ones along the way. Even solitary armigers tend to frequent common places when resting in towns or keep a pet with them while on the road, and even malevolent armigers keep a retinue of underlings. Regardless of their background, armigers share much with each other, but perhaps the most terrifying thing they share is the unspoken fear that without their bonds (to their arsenal and to others), they are nothing. Worst of all, because many of their abilities stem from their connections, the tragic reality is that their fear might be true.

entries.name: Creating an Armiger
entries: Armigers are people whose bonds mean a lot to them, whether that bond is a blade, an ideology, or a loved one. As you create an armiger, consider especially what your armiger connects with. These could be items, people, places, or ideas. Why does your armiger connect to these things? How do they connect with them? What about these connections might affect how your armiger abilities appear or are used? Do these connections serve as a source of power for your armiger's abilities?

It is also important to think about how your armiger discovered and developed their abilities in the first place, and how that affects their future growth. Do they come from a line of noble armigers, receiving training and tutelage from the family's court? Were they the child of a humble weaponsmith and always felt an invisible thread to their parent's heirloom that awoke their power on the day that it was gifted to them? Perhaps they learned of their abilities later in life, when they crossed paths with a sentient weapon that unlocked something inside the armiger that was always there?

Finally, take some time to ponder your armiger's arsenal (their bonded weaponry and armory), since it is a reflection of your armiger. Does your armiger prefer a certain type of weapon? Do their weapons take on a specific appearance when bonded - even if its a simple sigil of ownership? What does their armory look like and why does it look that way? When your armiger gets access to Links, what do these links appear as - tattoos? Strange runes? Meaningful figurines? Floating halos of power?

entries.name: Quick Build
entries: You can make an armiger quickly by following these suggestions. First, Charisma should be your highest ability score, followed by Dexterity. Second, choose the {@background courtier|scag}, {@background entertainer|phb}, {@background variant noble (knight)|phb|knight}, or {@background noble|phb} background.
